metadata.title: Enhanced selective catalytic reduction of NO over Mn-Ce catalysts with the acetic-acid-chelated titania support at low temperature

APCATA 16188 S0926-860X(17)30128-X 10.1016/j.apcata.2017.03.029 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 NO conversion of xCe-yMn catalysts on the TAc and ST01 supports at different temperatures. (a) 0Ce-10Mn, (b) 0Ce-20Mn, (c) 0Ce-30Mn, and (d) 7.5Ce-30Mn. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 NO conversion of Mn-Ce catalysts on various supports as a function of temperature. The procedure of preparation for the P25 (Evonik) or TiO2(S) (synthesized by the sol-gel method [32]) supported catalysts is the same as that for 7.5Ce-30Mn/TAc, except that TAc solution is replaced by P25 or TiO2(S) aqueous solution, denoted as 7.5Ce-30Mn/P25 or 7.5Ce-30Mn/TiO2(S). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the TAc (a) and ST01 (b) supported xCe-yMn catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Photographs of the suspensions that the ST01 and TAc, respectively, immersing into the mixture of manganese nitrate and cerium nitrates at different times. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 SEM images of the TAc supported xCe-yMn catalysts. (a) 0Ce-10Mn/TAc, (b) 0Ce-20Mn/TAc, (c) 0Ce-30Mn/TAc, and (d) 7.5Ce-30Mn/TAc. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 SEM images of the walls of honeycombs: (a) pristine, (b) coated with 7.5Ce-30Mn/ST01, and (c) coated with 7.5Ce-30Mn/TAc. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Resulting Photographs of the 7.5Ce-30Mn/ST01 (left) and 7.5Ce-30Mn/TAc (right) coated on glass substrates after a peeling test. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 NO conversion as a function of catalytic temperature over 7.5Ce-30Mn/ST01 and 7.5Ce-30Mn/TAc coated on honeycombs. Fig. 8 Table 1 Variation of Mn concentration on the various support slurries as shown in Fig. 4 and the corresponding BET surface areas. Table 1 Samples ST01 slurry TAc slurry upper middle lower upper middle lower Normalized concentration of Mn a 1.03 0.83 1.13 1.01 0.96 1.02 Standard deviation 0.15 0.03 BET surface area b , m2/g 123.0 129.7 a Determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (OPtiMA 5100DV, Perkim Elmer). b Measured after the slurry was calcined in a tubular oven under air atmosphere at 500°C for 1h. Enhanced selective catalytic reduction of NO over Mn-Ce catalysts with the acetic-acid-chelated titania support at low temperature Bo-Tau Liu a ⁎ Chung-Jie Huang a Yu-Xuan Ke a Wei-Hong Wang b Han-Lin Kuo b Darren Lin c Vincent Lin c Sung-Hwa Lin d a Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering, National Yunlin University of Science and Technology, Yunlin 64002, Taiwan Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering National Yunlin University of Science and Technology Yunlin 64002 Taiwan b Chemical Systems Research Division, Chung-Shan Institute of Science and Technology, Taoyuan 32599, Taiwan Chemical Systems Research Division Chung-Shan Institute of Science and Technology Taoyuan 32599 Taiwan c KJ Environmental Technology co., Ltd., Maioli 36143, Taiwan KJ Environmental Technology co., Ltd. Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering National Yunlin University of Science and Technology Yunlin 64002 Taiwan Graphical abstract In the study, we used the titania chelated with acetic acid (TAc) as the supports to prepare the highly active titania supported Mn-Ce catalysts for selective catalytic reduction of NO at low temperature. Characterization of the titania supported catalysts and the corresponding catalytic activity for NO removal were analyzed and evaluated. The TAc supported catalysts showed better Mn-Ce dispersion and catalytic activity for NO removal than the commercial TiO2 supported ones. Besides, the TAc supported catalysts also showed strong bonding at the TAc/TAc and the TAc/substrate interfaces, maintaining the integrity of the film after peeling test. We evaluated the catalytic activity for selective catalytic reduction of NO over the Mn-Ce catalysts wash-coated on ceramic monolith. Compared to the commercial TiO2 supported catalyst, the TAc supported one significantly enhanced the NO conversion by a factor of 1.25 and 1.58 times at 150 and 210°C, respectively. We speculate that the enhancement may arise from highly/uniformly-dispersed active centers on the surface of the TAc and the solidified structure of the coating layer. The well-dispersed active centers and the firm structure led to higher real space time when the NO stream flowed through the channels of the honeycombs, thereby resulting in a higher NO conversion. Keywords Nitrogen oxide Selective catalytic reduction Mn-Ce catalyst TiO2 Acetic acid 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) generated from high-temperature combustion, causing acid rain, ozone depletion, and photochemical smog, are major air pollutants to be significantly harmful to environment and human health [1,2]. The selective catalytic reduction (SCR) method using NH3 as a reductant is regarded as the most effective process to remove NOx. A commercialized catalyst V2O5-WO3 (or MoO3)/TiO2 exhibits high activity for the process in the temperature range of 300–400°C [3–6]. Unfortunately, the temperature range is much higher than the downstream temperature from the desulfurization and particle-removal devices. Reheating the flue gas is inevitable in the typically NH3-SCR process. Therefore, to save energy, there is an increasing interest in developing low-temperature SCR catalysts for NOx removal, especially lower than 150°C[7]. Many transition metal oxides have been studied extensively and showed potential for low-temperature SCR reaction [8–15]. Pena et al. [16] reported the activity for various transition metal oxides over the TiO2 support decreased the following order: Mn>Cu≥Cr≫Co>Fe≫V≫>Ni, where manganese oxides (MnOx) showed the best candidate as the low-temperature SCR catalyst due to the nature of labile oxygen [10,17–21]. CeO2 has been regarded as a promoter on the SCR catalysts as a result of its oxygen storage and redox couple Ce3+/Ce4+ [22]. Recently, Mn-Ce oxides catalyst has been found to have extraordinary activity for the SCR of NO [23–28]; the conversion of NO can be higher than 80% at 80°C [29]. It was also found that the TiO2 supported Mn-Ce catalyst exhibited a higher activity for SCR of NO than the Al2O3 supported one at low temperature due to the fact that TiO2 provided highly dispersion of MnOx on its surface [30] and abundant Lewis acid sites for NH3 adsorption and NO reduction [31]. Most of the low-temperature SCR catalysts were prepared by the impregnation method. The limit of dispersion and loading of the active materials might reduce the NO conversion. Although an attempt was made to solve the above-mentioned issues by using the sol-gel method, it took long time for the catalyst preparation [32–34]. In practical application, the SCR catalysts were wash-coated on metallic or ceramic monolith to alleviate pressure loss [35]. The good mechanical strength of the catalysts is desired. In addition, the well dispersion of the active centers on the support is very important because the high Mn loading may lead to crystalline formation, decreasing performance in SCR reaction [32]. Recently, the anatase TiO2 chelated with acetic acid (TAc) have been synthesized at low temperature [36]. The TAc features high active reaction through Ti-OH on its surface. The shrinkage of hydroxyl groups by the sol-gel reaction led to strong bonding and very low interfacial resistance among TAc [37,38]. In this study, we used the TAc as the support to prepare Mn-Ce catalysts for SCR of NO. Characterization of the TAc supported Mn-Ce catalysts and the corresponding catalytic activity for NO removal were analyzed and evaluated. Compared to the commercial TiO2 supported catalysts, the TAc supported ones showed superior mechanical strength, Mn-Ce dispersion, and catalytic activity for NO removal. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The TAc was synthesized using a sol-gel method, as reported previously [38]. Briefly, titanium(IV) isopropoxide (12g, TTIP, Sigma-Aldrich) was mixed with acetic acid (2.4g). Then, the mixture was added into DI water (200g). The aqueous solution became turbid immediately. After stirring at room temperature for 12h, nitric acid (2g) was added to the aqueous solution, which was then heated at 80°C for 90min, resulting in a stable light-blue titania sol chelated with acetic acid (TAc solution, 1.95%, w/w). The calculated amounts of manganese nitrate hydrate (99.98%, Alfa Aesar) and cerium nitrate hexahydrate (99.5%, Acros Organics) were added into the TAc solution. After 10-min mixture, the Mn/Ce TAc slurry was dried at 100°C. The dried powders were ground and then calcined in a tubular oven under air atmosphere at 500°C for 1h, resulting in xCe-yMn/TAc, where x and y denoted the weight percent of Ce and Mn over TAc used in the preparation of the samples, respectively. For comparison, the commercial TiO2 powders (ST01, ISK), which have the same crystalline phase (anatase) as the that of TAc, were also used as supports for the preparation of SCR catalysts. The procedure of preparation for the ST01 supported catalysts is the same as that for xCe-yMn/TAc, except that TAc solution was replaced by ST01 aqueous solution, denoted as xCe-yMn/ST01, where x and y denoted the weight percent of Ce and Mn to ST01 used in the preparation of the samples, respectively. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The morphologies of the as-prepared catalysts and those of the catalysts coated on honeycombs were examined using a field-emission scanning electron microscope (S4800-1, Hitachi). The crystalline phases of the catalysts were characterized through X-ray diffraction (XRD) using an X-ray diffractometer (Miniflex II, Rigaku) and Cu Kα radiation. The dispersion of the Mn and Ce on the surface of titania support was examined using an energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS). 2.3 Measurement of catalytic activity The activity tests for the SCR of NO were performed with a fixed-bed-reactor system at various temperature (60–240°C). We replaced quartz by stainless steel for the fixed-bed reactor to avoid the occurrence of TiO2 photocatalytic reaction. Catalysts (0.3g) and quartz powders (13.6g) were mixed and then loaded in the reactor. A gas mixture consisted of 75-ppm NO, 75-ppm NH3, 4.3% O2 and balance N2 was conducted into the reactor, corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 11,0000h−1. The NO concentration in the flow stream was analyzed using an electrochemical detector (Pac 7000 NO, Drager). The Mn/Ce TAc (or ST01) slurry was also wash-coated on cordierite honeycombs (100 cpsi) for the activity test under the same test conditions as tested for the powder-type catalysts. 3 Results and discussion The as-prepared TAc reveals pure anatase phase (Fig. S1), distributed over the range from 14 to 21nm with an average diameter of ∼19nm (Fig. S2). The FTIR spectrum of the crystalline TAc exhibits adsorptions at 1509 and 1410cm−1, which denote asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylic groups, respectively (Fig. S3). Compared with free carboxylic acids, the bands occur shifting, indicating the formation of chemical bonds between the carboxylic groups and Bronsted acid sites of the titania surface [39]. Fig. 1 shows that the NO conversion varies as a function of catalytic temperature; addition of Ce into the titania supported Mn catalysts enhances significantly the activity for SCR of NO. For various Mn-Ce compositions, the TAc supported catalysts reveal better catalytic activity than ST01 supported ones although the difference is not remarkable. In fact, the TAc supported catalyst also displays the better performance for NO conversion that other supported catalysts (Fig. 2 ). To realize the cause of the enhancement arisen by the TAc supports, crystalline phases of Mn-Ce catalysts over TAc and ST01 supports were analyzed. For both TAc and ST01 supported catalysts, the XRD patterns indicate peaks with values of 2θ located at 25.2, 37.8, 47.6, and 54.4°, corresponding to the (101), (004), (200), and (105), respectively, of anatase TiO2 (JCPDS #21-1272) (Fig. 3 ). No peak for Mn or Ce can be observed in the XRD patterns of TAc supported catalysts. The result implies that Mn and Ce are in a highly dispersed state or their crystallites formed are less than 5nm on the surface of TAc [17], which were consistent with the observation on EDS analysis (Fig. S4). As to the ST01 supported catalysts, there are three additional dominant peaks located at 2θ values of 28.9 and 37.3°, ascribed to the (110) and (211) of α-MnO2 (JCPDS #44-0141), and located at that of 32.7°, corresponding to the (222) of Mn2O3 (JCPDS #41-1442). The result indicates that manganese oxide is easier to form large crystals on the surface of ST01 than on that of TAc. The crystalline structure of manganese oxide has been shown to deteriorate the existence of oxygen vacancies and reduce catalytic performance [40]. We infer that the well dispersed manganese oxides on the surface of TAc may be attributed to the chelating of metal ions during calcination process by the carboxyl groups on the surface of TAc. Table 1 shows that TAc supports have slightly larger specific surface area that ST01 ones. As a result, the catalytic enhancement may arise from the fact that the TAc supports lead to additional surface and highly dispersed active centers. Due to numerous hydroxyl and carboxyl groups on the surface, the TAc was well dispersed in aqueous solution, whereas ST01 powders easily settled down in solution (Fig. 4 ). Therefore, the distribution of active centers was different when catalysts were prepared by immersing the titania supports into active metal solution. Table 1 shows the normalized concentration distribution of Mn for the catalysts prepared by the impregnation method. The ST01 supported catalysts reveal large variation on Mn concentration, but the TAc supported catalysts does almost uniform Mn-concentration distribution. Fig. 5 displays the SEM images of the TAc supported catalysts after high-temperature calcination. No large aggregates were observed for the TAc supported catalysts. The large aggregates may affect the application of the catalysts on monoliths. We wash-coated the catalysts on the on cordierite honeycombs. The TAc supported catalysts formed a compacter layer on the wall of the honeycomb than the ST01 supported catalysts (Fig. 6 ). Observing the results after the peeling test (Fig. 7 ), the layer of the TAc supported catalyst was tight and stuck firmly on substrates, maintaining the integrity of the layer against the adhesion attack, whereas the layer of ST01 supported catalyst was totally peeled off. This implies that the TAc make strong bonding at the TAc/TAc and the TAc/substrate interfaces. The observation is consistent with the previous result, where the enhancement was ascribed to the fact that the condensation reaction between TAc/TAc and TAc/substrate were catalyzed by the numerous acetates chelated on the surface of TAc [38]. Due to the fact that the carboxylic groups of TAc were disappeared after calcination at 500°C (Fig. S3), we suppose that the acetate chelating is helpful to the dispersion of metal ions and the chemical bonding at TAc/TAc or TAc/substrate interfaces during the calcination process, but not to NH3 adsorption or NO reduction as acid sites during the catalytic process. Fig. 8 shows the NO conversion over the Mn-Ce catalysts coated on honeycombs. The TAc supported catalyst reveals superior activity compared to the ST01 supported catalyst; the NO conversion was enhanced by a factor of 1.25 and 1.58 times at 150 and 210°C, respectively. We suppose that the enhancement may arise from highly/uniformly-dispersed active centers on the surface of the TAc and the solidified structure of the coating layer. When the NO stream flowed through the channels of the honeycombs, the uniform distribution of active centers might prevent the NO flow from bypassing them and avoid insufficiency of local active centers; the firm/dense structure reduces the risk of the damage by flow and increase the exposed surface area of the catalysts. The results led to higher real space time, thereby resulting in a higher NO conversion. 4 Conclusions The highly active titania supported Mn-Ce catalysts for SCR of NO at low temperature have been prepared by using TAc as the supports. Compared to the commercial TiO2 supported catalysts, the TAc supported catalysts showed good Mn-Ce dispersion and catalytic activity for NO removal. When wash-coating the TAc supported Mn-Ce catalysts on ceramic monolith, the NO conversion was enhanced significantly by a factor of 1.25 and 1.58 times at 150 and 210°C, respectively. The enhancement may arise from uniformly dispersed active centers on the surface of the TAc and the solidified structure of the coating layer, leading to higher real space time, thereby resulting in a higher NO conversion. coredata.dc:description: In the study, we used the titania chelated with acetic acid (TAc) as the supports to prepare the highly active titania supported Mn-Ce catalysts for selective catalytic reduction of NO at low temperature. Characterization of the titania supported catalysts and the corresponding catalytic activity for NO removal were analyzed and evaluated. The TAc supported catalysts showed better Mn-Ce dispersion and catalytic activity for NO removal than the commercial TiO2 supported ones. Besides, the TAc supported catalysts also showed strong bonding at the TAc/TAc and the TAc/substrate interfaces, maintaining the integrity of the film after peeling test. We evaluated the catalytic activity for selective catalytic reduction of NO over the Mn-Ce catalysts wash-coated on ceramic monolith. Compared to the commercial TiO2 supported catalyst, the TAc supported one significantly enhanced the NO conversion by a factor of 1.25 and 1.58 times at 150 and 210°C, respectively. We speculate that the enhancement may arise from highly/uniformly-dispersed active centers on the surface of the TAc and the solidified structure of the coating layer. The well-dispersed active centers and the firm structure led to higher real space time when the NO stream flowed through the channels of the honeycombs, thereby resulting in a higher NO conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced selective catalytic reduction of NO over Mn-Ce catalysts with the acetic-acid-chelated titania support at low temperature
